user_specs: ['Eye Color Hazel', 'Hair color Brunette', 'Skin Tone Fair', 'Skin Type Dry']
review_content: The only thing wrong with this is that I didn’t get it sooner. Perfect neutral subtle contour shade for my fair olive skin. Get the compact to put it in - I had a single blush and never used it but when I put it together with this in a compact now I’m using them both like crazy.

user_specs: ['Eye Color Brown', 'Hair color Black', 'Skin Tone Light', 'Skin Type Combination']
review_title: 5 Stars for the Product, 3.5 Stars for the Size
review_content:
I recently purchased this blush in the shade La Vie en Rose. This product gives my cheeks a beautiful nude-pink flush and it fits right in with my preferred color family as far as cheek products go. However, I was not expecting it to be as tiny as it is! One could argue that it's a good product to keep in your makeup bag for that reason, but I was very surprised when I actually opened the package. When I went to check out the metrics on other comparable blushes, the value for money actually isn't far off from other blushes within the same price range. I'm thinking the packaging might account for the jarring physical differences. Here is this blush and other blushes in my collection that are within the same color family. Surratt Beauty Artistique Blush - $32 | 0.14 oz/ 4 g. NARS blush - $30 | 0.16 oz/ 4.8 g. Charlotte Tilbury blush - $40 | 0.28 oz/ 8g. HOURGLASS Ambient Lighting Mini Blush Mini - $24 | 0.04 oz/ 1.3 g. LORAC Color Source Buildable Blush - $23 | 0.17. Tarte 9 Ways Cheek to Chic Blush | (9 cheek products for $35) | 0.077 oz/ 2.2 g per pan. The NARS blush is $2 cheaper than the Surratt Beauty blush and is .2 oz bigger. The Charlotte Tilbury blush is $8 more but has twice as much product. I ultimately decided to keep this blush because it really is a pretty shade and I think it will be a good blush to have in my makeup bag because it is so slim. However, I wish the packaging wasn't as flimsy - there is no contact, it's just a plastic deck and the pan slides in and out. Hopefully this reviewed helped some of you out there who are interested in buying this product!
…read more

user_specs: ['Eye Color Brown', 'Hair color Brunette', 'Skin Tone Fair', 'Skin Type Dry']
review_content: Ever put on a blush that immediately puts a spring in your step? This has just a touch of sophisticated shimmer with absolutely gorgeous pigment. Chaleur can be used as blush or contour on my fair skin. Yes, it's a small package, but a little goes a very long way so it will last a very long time. When I saw the quality of this product I turned around and purchased several more shades, along with the palettes.

user_specs: ['Eye Color Green', 'Hair color Blonde', 'Skin Tone Light', 'Skin Type Combination']
review_content:
I have light to light medium skin which is neutral leaning a little warm. For reference , Tarte Foundcealer in 27n is my summer foundation color. I bought this in Chaleur which is described as sun kissed nude. I think that description is accurate. It is a warm peachy brownish nude that looks like I spent the day at the beach but with sunscreen and a hat. It’s a hint of color that makes a difference for those of us who like natural looking makeup. This has a bit of a sheen but is close to matte. It’s very sheer and natural looking. You can build the color or layer it with another blush or bronzer. I do it with Laura Mercier Bronze 2 bronzer. I’ve bought a couple of Surratt brushes, Lipsliques, and this is my second blush. ( the other is actually the contour color.) i’m impressed with the brand and the formulation of this blush. I will probably pick up a few more.

review_title: A small pan but it packs a (pigmented) punch
review_content:
I bought both Guimauve and La Vie En Rose, and let me start out saying I'm deducting a star from both only because the pan sizes are so small for a $32 blush. To be blunt, each pan is about the size of two large eyeshadows. Smaller than the Nars pans by about a 1/3. Anyway. Besides my clear issue over the size, these are beautiful, pigmented colors that blend like a dream. I like to use them as eyeshadows as well as blushes, especially since Guimauve makes me look a bit too doll-like when I use it as a blush. So as long as you're okay with the price versus the pan size, this is a good purchase.

user_specs: ['Age 25-34', 'Eye Color Brown', 'Hair color Black', 'Skin Tone Medium', 'Skin Type Dry']
review_content: I have this blush in 9 (9!) colours and I love them all. The colours range from muted and subtle to bold and bright. The formula is incredibly soft and silky, it applies smoothly and even the paler colours, like Parfait, are bright with just one sweep. It's expensive for the size of the product, but the quality of the product is superior to my Nars, Tom Ford and Chanel blushes. On me, the colour lasts all day.

review_content:

review_title: Subtle true pink blush - a whisper...
review_content:
I was nervous to buy this until I tried it in store- as per all the other Surratt products (a) you must buy a protector for this and (b) it is highly pigmented and very finely milled, so a light hand is a must and you should probably use a goat hair brush. This color is amazing- it blends out to be a shimmery glisten of light pink which looks amazing. The photos on the sephora website don't do it justice. It's not chalky - it's a hint of the most beautiful light true pink that blends easily with highlighter and bronzer or alone. LOVE this. So happy I splurged. A little goes a very long way. Don't be thrown off by the small product size.

review_content:
I am so excited that Sephora is carrying Surratt- great brand. NOTE: you do need to buy the carrying case (not expensive) for your products- they are very delicate and small and need protection. This is a beautiful light highlighter that I bought that shimmers (no glitter) and I bought it with two blushes that I put in the compact. It is highly pigemented, a light hand is needed or a very soft (goat hair) brush... it is stunning. Everytime I wear it people say I look healthy and beautiful and it truly completes the look. The picture here makes it look coral toned, but it truly is more champagne hued but without a yellow undertone (confusing...but good) which makes it just an iridescent highlighter. I find it suits my neutral skin tone perfectly and blends seamlessly with either Surratt blushes or any of my other blushes and bronzers. LOVE LOVE LOVE

user_specs: ['Age 25-34', 'Skin Type Combination', 'Skin Tone Medium', 'Eye Color Brown']
review_title: I can't stop using these blushes!
review_content:
I have 2 XL empty palettes filled with blushes from different brands as well cheek palettes from Tarte and Nars. After owning 2 Surratt blushes, I feel kind of silly having all of these other blushes because I hardly ever use them anymore. I use both Chaleur and La Vie En Rose simultaneously (high maintenance, I know). I like to sweep Chaleur across my cheeks from apple to ear, and I swirl La Vie En Rose just on my apples. It gives such a beautiful and natural flush to my cheeks and goes well with most make-up looks I do. The powder feels so soft and buttery and applies so beautifully. It has the perfect amount of pigmentation and blends seamlessly on top of foundation. This blush is admittedly quite pricey when you consider how small the pan is, but it really is the most gorgeous blush I've ever used so far. As far as packaging concerns that other people are mentioning, I don't have a problem with it. This product is meant more for pro artists so it has to be small and compact, like the Viseart palettes. Surratt sells their own empty pallettes and these are supposed to pop right inside them. I just took out the plastic cover, stuck a magnet on the back, and put this in one of my own empty palettes.

I had to warm up to this brand. At first I was disappointed. Now I own 6 of these blush shades. The formula is thin but feels like silk and melts into the skin. The shades that I've tried that have shimmer aren't garish or chunky, but refined and subtle. They add a realistic glow to the skin. They are buildable so it's hard to over-do it (at least with the shades I own). I like everything except the packaging. The pans come in cheap, thin plastic and adhere to the palettes with a sticker. A sticker. Seriously. For this price, I don't expect a sticker anything. Magnetic would be much more appropriate. But, I still enjoy the product and would recommend, but be aware of the packaging.

user_specs: ['Age 25-34', 'Skin Type Normal', 'Skin Tone Light', 'Eye Color Green']
review_content:
First I'll address the sizing issues. I really think that people are judging the size based on how it arrives. There isn't excess packaging, it comes as basic as could be because these are meant to be put into a palette!! For reference, they are .14oz, and a Nars blush is .16oz. Yes, you get a bit more for the $30 you pay for Nars, but I wouldn't say that an extra $2 for a bit less product is a huge deal which would make what you get to be "too small". I LOVE the ones I got. I got La Rosee du Soir (a very light peachy-nude which has the slightest of pink tints, very pretty) and Cherubique (a light-medium rose with more noticeable shimmer, very beautiful). They are super pigmented, smooth, and apply nicely to the cheeks. They last all day and are really some of the best blushes I've ever tried. I plan to get Aureole and Grisaille next, and will probably get more blushes once I have the money! I promise these are so worth it and you'll love them.

user_specs: ['Age 25-34', 'Skin Type Combination', 'Skin Tone Light', 'Eye Color Brown']
review_content:
The blush itself is beautiful: soft, pigmented, easy to blend, sophisticated shades and super finely milled. Four stars because of the packaging. I feel at the $30+ for 4 grams kind of price point, this product needs to come with a much more solid case. The match box kind of sliding design is just not luxurious nor user-friendly. The blush can slide out in my purse and get completely messed up; or, I can't touch up my cheeks because it doesn't come with a mirror. At $30 something a piece, I shouldn't be compelled to arrange them in a palette to feel the product is "complete". Each blush should be a stand-alone piece. I was actually thinking, the product might have been a lot more popular if it come with a full packaging, which would most definitely make the blush appear to be "bigger" and the overall product to be more expensive because right now it just looked too much like an over-priced thin slice of colored powder.

review_title: love the coutour but size too small
review_content: Real love this coutour blush. Really easy to apply. The product comes in a very tiny piece of plastic holder. Price is a little bit high compared to the size. I highly recommend buying the duo or triple blush holder from surratt and make those a palette .

user_specs: ['Age over 54', 'Skin Type Dry', 'Skin Tone Medium', 'Eye Color Brown']
review_content:
The Surratt blushes have spoiled me for any other. The colors (I have Parfait, Canteloupe, Vie en Rose) give a realistic flush that meshes seamlessly with the skin. Pigmentation is intense so I use a very soft brush that deposits small amounts of color. Buffing each layer into the skin will intensify the color and ensures diffused edges. I don't care about the packaging because mine go into a Z-paleete anyway but if you are into luxe compacts, this doesn't cut it. It is costly but I need less of this than other powder blushes. There is no dupe that I'm aware of. I'd love to see Troy S. extend the color range, just as he has for his lip crayons.

user_specs: ['Age 25-34', 'Skin Type Oily', 'Skin Tone Fair', 'Eye Color Blue']
review_content:
I bought the contour shade hoping to find the perfect contour shade for pale, cool-toned skin, and unfortunately, this just isn't it. It is not very pigmented, and is rather blah (not a good descriptor), and makes me look muddy. It is fortunately cool-toned enough, but the size of the product (TINY) for $30+ makes it difficult to get enough product on my contour brush to apply my contour. It is 1" by 1.5" in size, which is unacceptable. It is the size of an eye shadow, which for the size of a contour/face product, is just ridiculous. It also contains a bit of shimmer. This may get returned.

Most of the negative reviews are about the packaging. This line is made to go into palettes, which are sold separately. The plastic case this comes in is not meant for traveling. You can get single, double, or eye and cheek mixed palettes. This line is beautiful and the texture is almost whipped. The cantaloupe shade is unlike anything you can find in any other line and is a very wearable bright pop of color. The contour shade is also the most natural looking contour for fair to medium skin available.

user_specs: ['Age 18-24', 'Skin Type Normal', 'Skin Tone Olive', 'Eye Color Brown']
review_title: Purchased Rouger nice but packaging is 3
review_content:
I give this review a 4 stars because for $32 on blush, the packaging could be better. It's nice that it easily slides but I'd recommend putting it in a palette with a magnetic bottom or taping the over over it if you want to put it in your purse. The plastic slider is nice because you can see the color. The blush is small and easy to travel with. The problem is that the cover slides off way too easily, that the product can rub off and crumble in your bag if you aren't careful. The product itself is beautiful. Nice color payoff and buildable. Very silky as others have said. The color pictured on the website for Rouger, looks different than in real life. Or maybe it's my monitor settings. To describe it, I like to think of a rich rhubarb color. It's warm toned. I recommend it for all skin tones. For light skin tones I would say use a light amount on your fluffy cheek brush. You can build it if you want it more noticeable. Light pressure during application. Medium/tan skin tones (which I am), I would say you can use two layers of this lightly. It gives such a nice warm glow. Darker skin tones, it will really bring your look together. It's bright but a rich bright color. It's not like a neon bright color. It has depth and warmth so it compliments your skin tone. I've use it on some clients and it shows up and looks great. I top it off with rose gold or copper becca highlighter.

user_specs: ['Age 45-54', 'Skin Type Dry', 'Skin Tone Fair', 'Eye Color Blue']
review_content:
The first thing that stands out about surratt's Artistique Blushes is the texture. Though definitely a powder, it's so silky and smooth that you'll swear it's a cream. The brand calls it slurry-technology, but I call it pixie magic as it's really unlike anything I've come across. And, I can't stop touching it as the texture is just so pleasing. There is absolutely zero kick-up when you run your brush across the pan and it applies as silky as it feels. I'm super-fair with cool undertones and I purchased Guimauve and La Vie En Rose along with the Petite Palette to give them a home. It was easy to peel off the labels on the bottoms of the blush pans and secure them into the palette. I know some are not pleased that this method requires purchasing at least two blushes or a combination of blush and eyeshadow, but, take heart and know that you're probably going to want at least two of these blushes in your life. Back to the shades...Guimauve is a light, candy-pink shade that looks a little bright in the pan, but applies as a soft, baby pink with ever-so-slight cool undertones. It's girly and lovely times a hundred. Though nicely pigmented, it is a light shade, so it may be best suited for fair to medium skintones. La Vie En Rose is a soft, neutral, rosy-pink with a hint of plum. In the pan, this looks a little brown and drab, but it comes to life on the skin and gives a gorgeous, subtle, rosy glow that looks prim, proper, and polished. It's one of those shades that should be universally flattering. Neither shade contains a hint of shimmer, but both provide soft illumination and create that coveted "lit-from-within" glow. They both apply like a dream with little to no blending. After using them exclusively for a few weeks, it's really difficult to go back to my other powder blushes as the texture of these is really unparalleled. I have my eye on several other shades and definitely want to try the highlighting shade (Aureole). I have a feeling there may be a Grande Palette in my future.

user_specs: ['Age 45-54', 'Skin Type Combination', 'Skin Tone Deep', 'Eye Color Brown']
review_content: i got La Vie en Rose. Super soft, blendable, easy to apply, natural color.

user_specs: ['Age 25-34', 'Skin Type Combination', 'Skin Tone Light', 'Eye Color Brown']
review_content: The color and texture are great. It's a flushy pink and goes on smoothly, with buildable color. I do wish for the price of adding it to a palette that it would at least be magnetized; instead they pieces are loose. The blush on its own has pretty weak packaging. I understand the whole minimal look and feel, but I have used brands that offer minimal but sturdy packaging. Definitely would be scared to drop this.

user_specs: ['Age 45-54', 'Skin Type Normal', 'Skin Tone Fair', 'Eye Color Gray']
review_content:
I like the product itself, but I don't like the packaging at all. The powder is ultra-fine milled, so the texture is first-rate, but the small package is difficult for me to manipulate...it feels as though the sliding container's plastic could crack if I put the tiniest bit of pressure on the case the wrong way. For this kind of money, I want this product to be a little gem to hold in the hand in addition to having terrifically vivid pigment and a velvety feel. I know it's a silly thing to dislike, but for the price-per-ounce, I want to at least get something that feels like it didn't come from the drugstore.

The pigment of the blush is wonderful. It goes on smoothly, and is build able. For $32 I expected better quality packaging. This feels cheap, imo.
A very pretty color and pigmented blush but super tiny for the price! I was a little disappointed by the size. I feel like it's not worth the price. Might not buy again!

user_specs: ['Age 25-34', 'Skin Type Oily', 'Skin Tone Deep', 'Eye Color Brown']
review_content: It's rare you come across the right "Melon" shade without it having too much orange or red undertones...Cantaloupe delivers the perfect peach with yellow undertones. It's brightens the cheeks and gives the most natural look. It's beautiful on my deep skin! I highly recommend.

user_specs: ['Age 18-24', 'Skin Type Combination', 'Skin Tone Fair', 'Eye Color Hazel']
review_content: I purchased Se Pomponner. It is a beautiful color but the packaging was SO flimsy I had to return. You can't put this in a make up bag because the cover will slide off. Its meant to be put into a palette. I returned it because I wanted something I could carry in my make up bag.

user_specs: ['Age 45-54', 'Skin Type Combination', 'Skin Tone Light', 'Eye Color Blue']
review_content:
I purchased Duchesse and La Vie En Rose, and also the compact that holds two blushes. Both blushes apply nicely but Duchesse is very light - so light that I will be using it as a matte brightener/highlighter (I have light skin). These blushes certainly didn't knock my socks off but for the price they should have!. There's not a lot of product and the packaging is just okay. I bought 2 blushes since I figure the compact holds two blushes and I may as well fill it up. What a marketing ploy to entice you into buying two (and I admit that I was foolish enough to fall for it!) The compact was just an extra expense, and I wish that I hadn't bought it. It leaves a bad taste in my mouth for shelling out so much for something that I don't feel is great. The blushes are not bad but for this much money and having to buy the compact for ease of use, I am left feeling disappointed. I won't be repurchasing.

review_content:
Se Pomponner is a vivid pink that is finely milled and applies and blends beautifully. I like the sleek packaging though it does look overly minimalistic for the price. Why the three stars? For some reason I've been into these brights that are supposed to be dotted on the cheek apple. They can add a real glow, when executed right. On me, Se Pomponner is fine..and I can usually wear these types of shades due to my coloring. Pretty, but that's it…for me. It would look lovely on darker toned folks. review_content: I like the color, but the amount of product is so little, I thought it was a sample. Also, I did not realize I need to purchase a case for the product separately. I consider this an outrageous fail.

user_specs: ['Age 25-34', 'Skin Type Normal', 'Skin Tone Medium', 'Eye Color Brown']
review_content:
I have been a fan of Surratt Beauty since the line launched at Barney's. I absolutely love that I can mix and match the blushes and eye shadows to make a customized palette. It's so handy. Surratt blushes are the only blushes I have in my collection. I love the formula that much. It is so silky and easy to blend. I currently have Grimauve, Duchesse (a bit too light for me), La Vie En Rose, Aureole, and Grisaille. (I have my eye on Cantaloup for summer.) Grimauve is my favorite - it's stunning. It's the perfect pink flush. The contour is also on heavy rotation for me - it's a fantastic color for my light skin. I keep a large custom case (also by Surratt) with the Grimauve, Grisaille and the Aureole highlighter. Having all three of those items in one neat palette has really streamlined my morning beauty routine. About the packaging - no, it isn't for everyone. The pans are not heavy. They're plastic. Because the blushes (and eye shadows) are meant to be placed into the palettes they are not really made to stand alone.
…read more

I was so excited to try a new brand. The colors of these blushes drew me in and next thing you know I've ordered three. Guess how many are going back? If you guessed three, you are a winner! These blushes are tiny! I have deluxe samples that are bigger! But it's not even the size that is my major issue. The packaging is junk. Flimsy and not even attractive. Once you get to the actual product true disappointment sets in. These are not very pigmented. I tried to get the to work but to no avail. And I am super fair, so colors shown up really well on my skin. For $32 I expected better color and more sturdy packaging. I guess I will stick to the brands I know are great.

user_specs: ['Age 25-34', 'Skin Type Combination', 'Skin Tone Fair', 'Eye Color Blue']
review_content:
I did my research before ordering 2 blushes and 2 eye shadows. I got blushes in La Vie en Rose and Parfat, and eye shadows in Patine and Cuivre (although I did not receive Cuivre as it must have sold out when they were fulfilling my order). Firstly, the quality of these products is amazing. I'm excited to try a new type of product, in that these use slurry technology to fill the pans. Secondly, I do like the palette packaging, HOWEVER, they really needed to add magnets. I ended up getting the grande palette instead of leaving the items loose, but you only just pop the items in there with no adhesive of any kind. Um, that makes me VERY nervous. I know when you close the lid, it'll keep the products in, but I still have a fear that they'll shift, crumble, or crack since they are not reinforced with glue or magnets. I'm hoping once I get my second eyeshadow, the palette will feel secure. For the price, they really should have come up with a packaging solution. I had to take 1 star off for that. We shall see!

user_specs: ['Age 25-34', 'Skin Type Combination', 'Skin Tone Light', 'Eye Color Brown']
review_content:
When I heard about surratt I was excited to try a new brand. Thinking they were out for a while they must be good, I finally ordered the highlighter. I heard it was small but once i saw it in person i was shocked. I've uploaded pics from my IG comparing it to the Kevyn Aucoin Candlelight highlighter. *size: On the left is the Kevyn Aucoin candlelight highlighter .11oz vs the surratt .14oz (box) or .2oz on product ; not sure which is correct. The packaging is so small ! Normally I wouldn't care but I personally find it so flimsy that I can't justify the price. It's a plastic pan and a clear tray that slides open, there's nothing practical about it. *pigment: to me I find the KA candlelight to be a softer highlighter for everyday use, but it is so much more pigmented whereas the surratt has to built up and isn't as bright as I would like. I'm not one that needs a metallic high shine highlighter but this was all fine sparkly bits and not a ton of color payoff. It really had to be built up for something that wasn't as spectacular after several layers This is unfortunately going back as I'm just not impressed and have others I prefer more. There is also a palette you can buy to customize yourself but the pans are not magnetic, and gluing or taping them in is inconvenient in the long run.

I bought this in La Vie En Rose. Truly a lovely neutral rose color. Great texture. Not thrilled with the flimsy packaging. It's assumed that you will purchase a separate palette to place the color and I might have, had there been a palette small enough to hold just one blush. I dislike it when lines assume I'm going to purchase and keep multiple items. One star off for the sub-standard packaging.

user_specs: ['Age over 54', 'Skin Type Dry', 'Skin Tone Fair', 'Eye Color Brown']
review_content:
I bought 4 blushes. The first blush, and my favourite, is Guimauve. It's a pretty, blue based, candy pink and is perfect for my fair complexion. It goes on soft and has a lovely stain finish. Duchess is the most stunning pale peach, but almost invisible on my pinkish cheeks. I'm keeping it anyway and hoping I can use it over something that is too dark. Grisaille is a contour and works for me because I'm fair. I'm not sure it will show up on someone with a darker complexion. It’s not completely matte, as we're told contours should be, but happily, the shimmer isn't visible on the skin. It gives a natural contour effect and I never see any harsh lines because it is so subtle. The last blush I bought was Aureole, which is a golden highlighter and yes, it's also finely milled, soft and creamy, but far too yellow based and with too much of a frosty finish.This was the only one I didn't love. I retuned it the next day.

review_content: I have rosy skin and I've had a hard time finding a coral blush that looks nice without fake tan on, but this color is perfect. I got the shade Ponceau after looking at swatches online and it's my new favorite everyday blush.

user_specs: ['Age 25-34', 'Skin Type Combination', 'Skin Tone Light', 'Eye Color Hazel']
review_title: Finally, a true Japanese formula powder blush!
review_content:
Some interesting things about these blushes: 1. It says 6g on the package but 4g on the case. To me it looks like 4g. 2. Like most Japanese brand makeup, these blushes are really really tiny small, they look big in the pictures though. The size is perfect for just adding a little liveness onto your cheeks daily. If you are to create your own palette this is good size.(2 eyeshadowa + 1 blush) 3. They are made using typical Japanese powder formula. It is kind of similar to Shiseido trio eyeshadow for the way how the shadows are slurried into the pan. (I guess slurry here means liquid into pan rather than dry pressed?) The texture however is better than the Shiseido shadows, more pigmented and silky, less powdery. 4. you may notice many Japanese powder makeup contain mineral oil/petrolatum. In north America people try to avoid it in cosmetics. I personally prefer mineral oil over natural oil for powder makeup just because it is more stable and last longer without having stale odour. It also makes the texture thinner and silkier.

user_specs: ['Age 25-34', 'Skin Type Combination', 'Skin Tone Light', 'Eye Color Brown']
review_title: Some are pigmented, some very sublte
review_content:
I have two of the light colors: Duchesse and Guimauve And one of the darker ones: Se Pomponner These are incredibly smooth and creamy feeling. They are soft, but do not kick up excess powder when brushed. The finish is a glitter-free luminous satin-matte. I think that the lighter shades are a bit too subtle, and I'll probably go through them trying to build up the color. They only show a little bit on me, and I have light skin. The texture is beautiful though, and it melds into the skin. The dark/bright color I have is beautiful. Very pigmented, a little bit is all that is needed. I thought I'd add some swatches and comparisons, since this brand is not widely available
